field_edited_text.value:
o ¢



xisting Conditions

Industrial Activity: Approximately
15,000 employees work in Canton’s more
than 20 manufacturing establishments. Most
of these businesses are concentrated in
four clusters. Bulk material producers, such
as Lebanon Chemical, and Lehigh Portland
Cement, are located on the harbor along
Clinton Street in west Canton. Although
located directly on the harbor, neither
Agrico nor Lehigh Portland make use of
their deepwater access for shipments. A
diverse group of medium and large manu-
facturers can be found along Boston Street
in north Canton. These include GAF Corp.,
Crown Cork and Seal, S. Schapiro and
Sons, and Quality Chemicals. East of New-
kirk Street are Canton’s major employers,
Lever Brothers and General Motors. These
companies employ over 5,000 persons on
approximately 150 acres of land in the
heart of Canton. Apart from other heavy
manufacturing activities, National Gypsum
maintains a facility at Newkirk and Newgate
Streets. Further east, along Colgate Creek,
is another cluster of manufacturers which
includes Universal Foods and SCM Glidden
Paints.

dministration



Maryland Port

View of Seagirt Marine Terminal under development, foreground; Dundalk, background.

..............

The area’s largest employers have been
in Canton since the 1930s. The General
Motors car and truck assembly plant began
operations in 1935, increasing in size from
46 to 167 acres since that time. Employment
at GM peaked at 6,991 in 1978 and has
since declined to 3,500. In 1981 the Balti-
more plant stopped making trucks and
began a major modernization of both plant
and equipment in preparation for produc-
ing the company’s new J-car. However,
decreasing auto sales caused a halt in the
modernization project until late 1982. At
that time a scaled back upgrading program
resumed. It is now anticipated that produc-
tion will center around small vans.

Western Electric Corporation began
operations here in 1929. The plant, which
at one time employed approximately 5,000
persons at its 169 acre Point Breeze site,
announced that it would phase-out its
Baltimore plant.

Lever Brothers has been in Canton
since 1939. The plant manufactures All and
Wisk detergent, Aim and Close-up tooth-
paste, and Dove soap; it employs 1,047
persons. Over the years the company has
made substantial investments in plant
modernization and pollution abatement
equipment. In 1982 the company began
construction of a $10 million sulphanami-
lide facility.

38
